Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Studies of Dynamics and Control of Quantum Many-Body Systems Far from Equilibrium
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical research and education on quantum many-body systems far from equilibrium. There are three main research thrusts:

1. Transport properties of integrable and nonintegrable systems far from equilibrium: The PI will focus on the conditions under which ballistic and diffusive transport behaviors are established. Both will be considered, that of isolated systems and that of systems interacting with two heat baths at different temperatures.

2. The conditions for thermalization in isolated quantum many-body systems. It has been argued that thermal equilibrium is achieved when the eigenstates of the system become chaotic. However, open questions remain. The PI will investigate how the system relaxes to equilibrium, particularly when the factors that prevent thermalization are included. The PI also aims to develop a proper definition of entropy for systems out of equilibrium.

3. The development of new quantum control methods to induce a desired transport behavior. The PI aims to develop tools to achieve, through dynamical decoupling techniques, regimes and phases of interest for theoretical and experimental studies of nonequilibrium quantum many-body systems.

These three research lines will be developed in parallel being amplified by the synergies that result from the study of different aspects of similar systems. Experiments will motivate the choice of models that will be used. Among these are experiments on thermal transport in magnetic compounds; on thermalization and quantum phase transitions in ultracold atoms trapped in optical lattices; and on control of magnetization and information transfer in spin systems.

This award also supports education and outreach activities with the goals: to continue engaging female undergraduate students in research projects, in part through new projects inspired by the research; to modernize the curriculum at Stern College for Women of Yeshiva University with new courses that expose all science students to programming and to concepts of modern physics at an early stage of their undergraduate studies; to create a webpage for posting computer codes from courses and research projects together with their explanations, aiming at contributing to the integration of teaching and research at other institutions; and to offer research opportunities for high school students in the New York area.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical research and education on how heat, magnetism, and information propagate through systems of electrons, or more generally through systems of many interacting particles that are described by the laws of quantum mechanics. These systems are generally very far from the balanced state of equilibrium. The PI aims to advance understanding of nonequilibrium quantum physics which is far less understood than equilibrium quantum physics. The research is likely to have impact beyond the specific context and may have impact on other disciplines from physics, chemistry, and materials to biology and climate. Specific goals of this project include understanding how the behavior of systems that are far from equilibrium unfolds with time, how such systems eventually relax to reach equilibrium, and how can nonequilibrium systems be controlled and manipulated to produce a desired outcome.

From a technological perspective, understanding and controlling the transport of heat, magnetization, and information in quantum systems of interacting particles is vital. One of the most challenging aspects in the development of new electronic devices, such as microchips and hard disks, for instance, is the mitigation of local heating. At the level of magnetization currents, the understanding and control of magnetization transport are essential for spintronics, where the magnetic properties of the electron are exploited in addition to the electron charge for device operation. Quantum computation and quantum information processing, which may revolutionize computation capabilities and encryption technology for security, also require efficient methods for the transport of information.

This award also supports education and outreach activities with the goals: to continue engaging female undergraduate students in research projects, in part through new projects inspired by the research; to modernize the curriculum at Stern College for Women of Yeshiva University with new courses that expose all science students to programming and to concepts of modern physics at an early stage of their undergraduate studies; to create a webpage for posting computer codes from courses and research projects together with their explanations, aiming at contributing to the integration of teaching and research at other institutions; and to offer research opportunities for high school students in the New York area.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT: NSF CAREER AWARD (2012-2017)
Award Title: CAREER: Studies of Dynamics and Control of Quantum Many-Body Systems Far from Equilibrium
Federal Award ID: 1147430

PI’S ACADEMIC ACCOMPLISHMENTS
The PI teaches at Stern College for Women, which is the undergraduate college of arts and sciences for women of Yeshiva University. The NSF-CAREER award allowed her to sustain a highly productive research program. She raised through the academic ranks to Associate Professor in 2013 and to Full Professor in 2014. She became the chair of the Physics Department of Stern College in 2016.

STATISTICS
*) The PI published 26 peer-reviewed papers (2 Physical Review Letters, 4 Rapid Communications, 1 Physics Reports, 3 for invited issues, 3 with undergraduate students) and 1 proceeding article.
*) According to Google Scholar, since 2012, the PI’s papers were cited 1184 times.
*) Her group gave 66 talks, from which 46 were invited talks presented by the PI and 3 were given by undergraduate students at March Meetings.
*) The PI advised 2 Latin American postdoctoral fellows. One became a physics professor and the other works for a start-up company.
*) The PI mentored 11 undergraduate students, 9 being women. Among these students, 9 went to graduate programs in physics and engineering, 1 became a physics high school teacher, and 1 plans to go to medical school.
*) The PI worked with 2 high school students over the summers. One became a computer science student at the MIT and the other an engineering student at Stony Brook.

SUMMARY OF THE PROJECT AND ITS ACCOMPLISHMENTS
This NSF-CAREER award supported theoretical research about the dynamics of systems with many interacting particles that are described by the laws of quantum mechanics, and it provided research opportunities to undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows.

*) Research: Despite ubiquitous, out-of-equilibrium many-body quantum dynamics are much less understood than quantum systems at or close to equilibrium. Understanding their properties is essential to a wide range of fields, from atomic, molecular, and condensed matter physics to quantum information and cosmology. Advances in nonequilibrium quantum dynamics are crucial for various scientific and technological applications. They may reveal new phases of matter that would lead to new materials. Quantum computation and quantum information processing, which may revolutionize computation capabilities and encryption technology for secure communications, require efficient methods to transfer excitations. Ways to transport heat rapidly are necessary to mitigate local heating and allow for the development of new electronic devices, such as microchips and hard disks.

The PI’s group was able to achieve a complete picture of the relaxation process of low-dimensional lattice many-body quantum systems, describing their dynamics at all different time scales, from the moment they are perturbed out of equilibrium to the moment of equilibration. Numerical and analytical results were obtained for various dynamical quantities that are of interest to experiments with cold atoms, ion traps, and nuclear magnetic resonance platforms.

In addition to describing the dynamics, the group also explored how to gain direct information about the systems by looking only at their time evolution. This approach is very useful to experiments that have partial or no access to the systems’ spectra. The group proposed different ways, where from analyzing only the dynamics, one can learn details about the properties of the system and its initial state.

*) Education and outreach: With this award, the PI was able to continue engaging female undergraduate students in her research projects; she developed a new computational course to expose all science students to programming; she created a webpage for posting computer codes from courses and research projects together with their explanations, aiming at contributing to the integration of teaching and research at other institutions; she gave lectures in summer schools and in visits to institutions, she took part of the ANACAPA meetings, which is a society that promotes research in physics at primarily undergraduate institutions; and she visited high schools for girls to talk about physics and about possible careers one can have with a physics degree.
